Composed by KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra
Tripiá¹­aka master Saá¹ƒghadeva of KaÅ›mÄ«ra during the Fu Qin dynasty

Chapter on Killing, Section on Killing, Third Section on Killing. Can one kill sentient beings without exhausting killing sentient beings, or can one not kill sentient beings while exhausting killing sentient beings?
Can one kill sentient beings while exhausting killing sentient beings, or can one not kill sentient beings while not exhausting killing sentient beings?
Can one not kill sentient beings while not exhausting killing sentient beings, and will one necessarily be reborn in hell due to that action?
Can one perform unwholesome and painful actions without fully ripening them, and will one necessarily have a defiled mind when first experiencing the results of those actions?

Can one kill a sentient being, not receive the precepts afterwards, and be considered pure with regard to all sentient beings?ğŸ”½If one is pure with regard to all sentient beings, do they all receive the precepts from that person?
If they all receive the precepts from that person, are they all pure with regard to that person?
If one has a body, does one have bodily action?
If one has bodily action, does one have a body?ğŸ”½If one has a body, does one have verbal action?
If one has verbal action, does one have a body?ğŸ”½If one has a body, does one have mental action?
If one has mental action, does one have a body?ğŸ”½If one has a body, does one have bodily action and verbal action?
If one has bodily action and verbal action, does one have a body?ğŸ”½If one has a body, does one have bodily action and mental action?
If one has bodily action and mental action, does one have a body?
If one has a body, does one have verbal action and mental action?ğŸ”½If one has verbal action and mental action, does one have a body?
If one has a body, does one have bodily action, verbal action, and mental action?ğŸ”½If one has bodily action, verbal action, and mental action, does one have a body? (End of the section on the body)
If one possesses bodily action, does one possess verbal action?
If one possesses verbal action, does one possess bodily action? If one possesses bodily action, does one possess mental action?
If one possesses mental action, does one possess bodily action?ğŸ”½If one possesses bodily action, does one possess verbal action and mental action?
If one possesses verbal action and mental action, does one possess bodily action?ğŸ”½If one possesses verbal action, does one possess mental action?
If one possesses mental action, does one possess verbal action?ğŸ”½If the practice of desire is not yet ended, is the retribution of desire not yet ended?
If the retribution of desire is not yet ended, is the practice of desire not yet ended?ğŸ”½If the practice of desire is ended, is the retribution of desire ended?
If the retribution of desire is ended, is the practice of desire ended?ğŸ”½If an action has a result, does that action have all retributions?
If an action has retributions, does that action have all results?
If an action has no result, does that action have no retribution?
If an action has no retribution, does that action have no result?
If an action is unwholesome, is that action all inverted?
If an action is inverted, is that action all unwholesome?ğŸ”½If an action is not unwholesome, is that action all not inverted?
If an action is not inverted, is that action all not unwholesome?ğŸ”½If one possesses unwholesome actions, does one possess form and formless realm actions?

If one possesses form and formless realm actions, does one possess unwholesome actions?ğŸ”½If one possesses wholesome actions of the desire realm, does one possess wholesome actions of the form and formless realms?

If one possesses wholesome actions of the form and formless realms, does one possess wholesome actions of the desire realm?ğŸ”½If one possesses actions of the desire realm, does one possess actions of the form realm?
If one possesses actions of the form realm, does one possess actions of the desire realm?
If one possesses form realm karma, does one possess formless realm karma?

If one possesses formless realm karma, does one possess form realm karma?ğŸ”½If one possesses form realm karma, does one possess form realm karma and pure karma?ğŸ”½If one possesses form realm karma and pure karma, does one possess form realm karma?

If one possesses form realm karma, does one possess formless realm karma and pure karma?ğŸ”½If one possesses formless realm karma and pure karma, does one possess form realm karma?ğŸ”½If one possesses form realm karma, does one possess formless realm karma and pure karma?
If one possesses formless realm karma and pure karma, does one possess form realm karma?
If one possesses formless realm karma, does one possess pure karma?ğŸ”½If one possesses pure karma, does one possess formless realm karma?
If one accomplishes the practices of the desire realm, form realm, formless realm, and the uncontaminated practices, where are they reborn after death?
I wish to hear a full explanation of the meaning of this chapter.
Can one harm sentient beings without exhausting the harm to sentient beings?
Answer:
Yes, such as when one cuts off the life of a sentient being, the expedient means do not cease, and the search continues.
Can one not harm sentient beings, yet exhaust the harm to sentient beings?
Answer:
Yes, such as when one does not harm the life of a sentient being, the expedient means cease, and the search ends.
Can one harm sentient beings, and exhaust the harm to sentient beings?
Answer:
Yes, such as when one harms the life of a sentient being, the expedient means cease, and the search ends.
Can one not harm sentient beings, yet the harm to sentient beings is not exhausted?
Answer:
Yes, such as when one does not harm the life of a sentient being, the expedient means do not cease, and the search continues.
Can one not harm sentient beings, yet the harm to sentient beings is not exhausted, and they will definitely be reborn in hell due to their actions and the consequences they experience?
Answer:
Yes, like when one performs an irredeemable action and dies in the middle.
Is there an unwholesome action whose painful retribution is not yet ripe, and for which one first receives its retribution, and then necessarily becomes defiled in mind?
Answer:
Yes, like when one performs an irredeemable action, and first receives the intermediate existence in hell.
Is there a case where one kills a living being, and later does not receive the precepts, and is said to be pure with respect to all living beings?
Answer:
Yes, like when one intends to kill a living being, and in the middle encounters the Dharma, or if one who has seen the truth is pure with respect to all living beings.
Do all those who receive the precepts with respect to all living beings receive the precepts with respect to all living beings in the past?
Answer:
There are those who are pure with respect to all living beings, but do not receive the precepts with respect to all living beings. This statement is based on the translator's intention to show.
What is meant by being pure with respect to all living beings, but not receiving the precepts with respect to all living beings?
Answer:
It is like not receiving precepts, but encountering the Dharma in the meantime. This is called pure for all sentient beings, but not receiving precepts for all sentient beings.
How is it that one receives precepts for all sentient beings, but is not pure for all sentient beings?
Answer:
It is like receiving precepts and transgressing precepts. This is called receiving precepts for all sentient beings, but not being pure for all sentient beings.
How is it that one is pure for all sentient beings and receives precepts for all sentient beings?
Answer:
It is like receiving precepts and not transgressing precepts. This is called being pure for all sentient beings and receiving precepts for all sentient beings.
How is it that one is not pure for all sentient beings and does not receive precepts for all sentient beings?
Answer:
Excluding the above cases.
If one possesses a body, does one have bodily actions?
Answer:
One may possess a body but not bodily actions.
How does one possess a body but not bodily actions?
Answer:

Ordinary people who are in the mother's womb with the egg membrane gradually thickening, if born in the desire realm without deportment and not in non-deportment, with no bodily action, even if there was action it would be lost, this is called accomplishing the body but not bodily action.
What is meant by accomplishing bodily action but not the body?
Answer:
The undefiled person born in the formless realm, this is called accomplishing bodily action but not the body.
What is meant by accomplishing the body and bodily action?
Answer:
The undefiled person in the mother's womb with the egg membrane gradually thickening, if born in the desire realm in deportment or not in deportment,

not in non-deportment and also not not in deportment, with bodily action, even if there was action it would not be lost, or if born in the form realm, this is called accomplishing the body and bodily action.
What is meant by not accomplishing the body and not bodily action?
Answer:
Ordinary people born in the formless realm, this is called not accomplishing the body and not bodily action.
If one accomplishes the body, does one have verbal action?
Answer:
One may possess bodily action but not verbal action.
How does one possess bodily action but not verbal action?
Answer:

If one is an ordinary person in the womb, gradually becoming thicker in the egg membrane, or if one is born in the desire realm, neither in a state of dignified deportment nor not in a state of dignified deportment, with no verbal expression, even if one has expression, one loses it. This is called possessing bodily action but not verbal action.
How does one possess verbal action but not bodily action?
Answer:
A stainless person born in the formless realm. This is called possessing verbal action but not bodily action.
How does one possess both bodily and verbal action?
Answer:

A stainless person in the womb, gradually becoming thicker in the egg membrane, or if one is born in the desire realm, either in a state of dignified deportment or not in a state of dignified deportment, with verbal expression, even if one has expression, one does not lose it, or if one is born in the form realm. This is called possessing both bodily and verbal action.
How does one not possess bodily action but not verbal action?
Answer:
Ordinary people born in the formless realm are said to not possess bodily actions but possess verbal actions.
If one possesses a body, do they possess mental actions?
Answer:
It is so, if one possesses a body, they possess mental actions.
Can one possess mental actions but not a body?
Answer:
Yes, those born in the formless realm.
If one possesses a body, do they possess bodily and verbal actions?
Answer:

One may possess a body but not bodily and verbal actions, or possess a body and bodily actions but not verbal actions, or possess verbal actions but not bodily actions, or possess bodily and verbal actions.
What is meant by possessing a body but not bodily and verbal actions?
Answer:

Ordinary people in the womb, gradually becoming thicker in the egg membrane, or if born in the desire realm, not in dignified deportment or not in undignified deportment, with no bodily or verbal expression, or even if having expression, having lost it, this is called possessing a body but not bodily and verbal actions.
What is meant by possessing a body and bodily actions but not verbal actions?
Answer:

If born in the desire realm, neither in dignified deportment nor not in dignified deportment, with bodily action, even if there is action it is not lost, with no verbal action, even if there is action it is lost - this is called possessing body and bodily action but not verbal action.
What is meant by possessing body and verbal action but not bodily action?
Answer:

If born in the desire realm, neither in dignified deportment nor not in dignified deportment, with verbal action, even if there is action it is not lost, with no bodily action, even if there is action it is lost - this is called possessing body and verbal action but not bodily action.
What is meant by possessing body and bodily action and verbal action?
Answer:

If in the membrane gradually thickening stage of the mother's womb, if born in the desire realm, either in dignified deportment or not in dignified deportment, not in dignified deportment nor not in dignified deportment, with bodily and verbal action, even if there is action it is not lost, if born in the form realm - this is called possessing body and bodily and verbal action.
If one possesses bodily and verbal actions, does one possess a body?
Answer:
Either one possesses or does not possess.
How does one possess?
Answer:
What was said above, this is called possessing.
How does one not possess?
Answer:
Those with outflows are born in the formless realm, this is called not possessing.
If one possesses a body, does one possess bodily actions and mental actions?
Answer:
Either one possesses a body and mental actions but not bodily actions, or one possesses bodily actions and mental actions.
How does one possess a body and mental actions but not bodily actions?
Answer:

Ordinary beings who gradually thicken the egg membrane and dwell in the mother's womb, or those born in the desire realm who are neither in a state of deportment nor not in a state of deportment, with no bodily expression or having lost it, this is called possessing a body and mental actions but not bodily actions.
How does one possess a body and bodily actions and mental actions?
Answer:

If a person without defilements is born in the desire realm, whether in a dignified posture or not, with or without bodily action, or if born in the form realm, this is called possessing both body and bodily and mental actions.
If one possesses bodily and mental actions, does one possess the body?
The answer is:
Either one possesses or does not possess.
How does one possess?
The answer is:
What was said above, this is called possessing.
How does one not possess?
The answer is:
A person without defilements born in the formless realm, this is called not possessing.
If one possesses the body, does one possess verbal and mental actions?
The answer is:
Either one possesses the body and mental actions but not verbal actions, or verbal and mental actions.
How does one possess the body and mental actions but not verbal actions?
The answer is:

Ordinary people, if born in the desire realm, neither in proper deportment nor not in proper deportment, with no verbal action, even if there is action it is lost, this is called accomplishing bodily and mental actions but not verbal actions.
What is meant by accomplishing bodily, verbal, and mental actions?
Answer:

Those without defilement, if born in the desire realm, either in proper deportment or not in proper deportment, with verbal action, even if there is action it is not lost, or if born in the form realm, this is called accomplishing bodily, verbal, and mental actions.
If one accomplishes verbal and mental actions, does one also accomplish bodily actions?
Answer:
Either one accomplishes or does not accomplish.
What is meant by accomplishing?
Answer:
What was mentioned above, this is called accomplishing.
What is meant by not accomplishing?
Answer:
Those without defilement born in the formless realm, this is called not accomplishing.
If one possesses body, do they have bodily, verbal, and mental actions?
Answer:

One may possess body and mental actions but not bodily or verbal actions, or possess body and mental actions but not verbal actions, or possess verbal and mental actions but not bodily actions, or possess bodily, verbal, and mental actions.
How does one possess body and mental actions but not bodily or verbal actions?
Answer:

If one is an ordinary person in the womb, gradually becoming thicker in the egg membrane, or if one is born in the desire realm, not in proper deportment nor not in improper deportment, with no bodily or verbal expression, even if one has expression one loses it. This is called possessing body and mental actions but not bodily or verbal actions.
How does one possess body and bodily and mental actions but not verbal actions?
Answer:

If one is born in the desire realm, not in proper deportment nor not in improper deportment, with bodily expression, even if one has expression one does not lose it, but with no verbal expression, even if one has expression one loses it. This is called possessing body and bodily and mental actions but not verbal actions.
How does one possess bodily and verbal and mental actions but not bodily actions?
Answer:

If one is born in the desire realm, neither in a state of deportment nor not in a state of deportment, with verbal expression, even if one has expression and does not lose it, without bodily expression, even if one has expression one loses it, this is called possessing bodily and verbal and mental actions but not bodily actions.
How does one possess bodily and bodily and verbal and mental actions?
Answer:

Those in the womb of a mother with gradually thickening egg membranes, those without defilements, if born in the desire realm, in a state of deportment, not in a state of deportment, neither in a state of deportment nor not in a state of deportment, with bodily and verbal expression, even if one has expression and does not lose it, if born in the form realm, this is called possessing bodily and bodily and verbal and mental actions.
If one possesses bodily and verbal and mental actions, does one possess a body?
Answer:
Either one possesses or does not possess.
How does one possess?
Answer:
What was said above, this is called possessing.
How does one not possess?
Answer:
If a person without defilements is born in the formless realm, this is called not yet possessing a body.
If one possesses bodily action, does one possess verbal action?
Answer:
One may possess bodily action but not verbal action.
How does one possess bodily action but not verbal action?
Answer:

If one is born in the desire realm, neither in a state of deportment nor not in a state of deportment, with bodily intimation, even if one has it, one does not lose it, with no verbal intimation, even if one has it, one loses it. This is called possessing bodily action but not verbal action.
How does one possess verbal action but not bodily action?
Answer:

If one is born in the desire realm, neither in a state of deportment nor not in a state of deportment, with verbal intimation, even if one has it, one does not lose it, with no bodily intimation, even if one has it, one loses it. This is called possessing verbal action but not bodily action.
How does one possess both bodily and verbal action?
Answer:

If a person without defilements is born in the desire realm, whether in a dignified posture or not, with bodily and verbal activity, even if there is activity but it is not lost, or if born in the form realm, a person without defilements born in the formless realm, this is called accomplishing bodily and verbal actions.
What is meant by not accomplishing bodily and verbal actions?
Answer:

If a person in the womb with gradually thickening egg membranes is an ordinary person, if born in the desire realm, neither in a dignified posture nor not in a dignified posture, with no bodily and verbal activity, even if there is activity it is lost, or if born in the formless realm as an ordinary person, this is called not accomplishing bodily and verbal actions.
If one accomplishes bodily actions, do they accomplish mental actions?
Answer:
It is so that if one accomplishes bodily actions, they accomplish mental actions.
Can one accomplish mental actions without accomplishing bodily actions?
Answer:

Yes, those who are gradually becoming more enclosed in the egg, abiding in the mother's womb, ordinary beings, if born in the desire realm, neither behaving nor not behaving, with no bodily action, even if there was action it was lost, or ordinary beings born in the formless realm.
If one accomplishes bodily action, does one also accomplish verbal and mental action?
Answer:
There are those who accomplish bodily action and mental action but not verbal action, and those who accomplish bodily, verbal, and mental action.
How does one accomplish bodily action and mental action but not verbal action?
Answer:

If born in the desire realm, neither behaving nor not behaving, with bodily action, even if there was action it was not lost, with no verbal action, even if there was action it was lost, this is called accomplishing bodily action and mental action but not verbal action.
How does one accomplish bodily action, verbal action, and mental action?
Answer:

If a person without defilements is born in the desire realm, abiding in deportment or not abiding in deportment, not abiding in deportment nor not abiding in deportment, with bodily and verbal activity, having had activity or not losing it, if born in the form realm, or a person without defilements born in the formless realm, this is called accomplishing bodily action and verbal and mental actions.
If one accomplishes verbal and mental actions, does one accomplish bodily action?
Answer:
Either one accomplishes it or not.
How does one accomplish it?
Answer:
What was said above, this is called accomplishment.
How is it not accomplished?
Answer:

If born in the desire realm, not abiding in deportment nor not abiding in deportment, with no bodily activity, having had activity or losing it, with verbal activity, having had activity or not losing it, this is called not accomplished.
If one accomplishes verbal action, does one accomplish mental action?
Answer:
In this way, if one accomplishes oral action, one also accomplishes mental action.
Can one accomplish mental action but not oral action?
Answer:

There is. Those in the egg-born stage, gradually thickening the membrane, dwelling in the mother's womb, ordinary beings, if born in the desire realm, neither behaving properly nor not behaving properly, with no verbal expression, even if there was expression it was lost, ordinary beings born in the formless realm.
If one has not yet ended the practice of sexual activity, has one not yet ended the retribution for sexual activity?
Answer:
In this way, if one has not yet ended the practice of sexual activity, one has not yet ended the retribution for sexual activity.
Can one have not yet ended the retribution for sexual activity but not the practice?
Answer:
There is. A stream-enterer who has ended the practice of sexual activity eliminated by seeing the truths, but has not yet ended the retribution for sexual activity.
If one has ended the practice of sexual activity, has one ended the retribution for sexual activity?
Answer:
In this way, if one has ended the retribution for sexual activity, one has ended the practice of sexual activity.
Can one have ended the practice of sexual activity but not the retribution?
Answer:
There is. For a stream-enterer, the actions abandoned by seeing the truths are exhausted, but the retribution for those actions is not yet exhausted.
If an action has a result, is that action exhausted and has it retribution?
Answer:
It is so. If an action has retribution, that action is exhausted and has a result.
Is there an action that has a result, but that action does not have retribution?
Answer:
There is. Unwholesome and unconditioned actions.
If an action has no result, is that action exhausted and has it no retribution?
Answer:
There is no action that does not have a result.
Is there an action that has no retribution?
Answer:
There is. Unwholesome and unconditioned actions.
If an action is unwholesome, is that action all inverted?
Answer:
There are actions that are unwholesome but not inverted.
What are actions that are unwholesome but not inverted?
Answer:
It is like a person who has views and opinions, who sees and speaks like this:
There are actions, and there are results of actions;
Their bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct.

It is like someone who has not seen thinking they have seen, has not heard, has not discerned, has not cognized thinking they have cognized. They do not think this, do not accept this, do not see this, do not wish this, do not have the wisdom of this: 'I have not seen, have not heard, have not discerned, have not cognized.'

It is like someone who has seen thinking they have not seen, has heard, has discerned, has cognized thinking they have not cognized. They do not think this, do not accept this, do not see this, do not wish this, do not have the wisdom of this: 'I have seen, have heard, have discerned, have cognized.'
This is called 'action that is unwholesome, but not inverted.'
What is 'action that is inverted, but not unwholesome'?
Answer:
It is like someone who has no view and no fruit, who sees thus and speaks thus:
'There is no action, no result of action.'
Their bodily good conduct, verbal good conduct, and mental good conduct.

It is like one who has not seen, but has the notion of having seen, has not heard, has not distinguished, has not cognized, but has the notion of having cognized, and with this notion, this acceptance, this view, this love, this wisdom, says: 'I see, hear, distinguish, and cognize.'

It is like one who has seen, but has the notion of not having seen, has heard, has distinguished, has cognized, but has the notion of not having cognized, and with this notion, this acceptance, this view, this love, this wisdom, says: 'I have not seen, heard, distinguished, or cognized.'
This is called inverted action, but that action is not unwholesome.
What is unwholesome action, and that action is inverted?
Answer:
It is like one who sees that there is no seeing, no fruit of reality, and with such a view, such speech,
says: 'There is no action, no fruit of action;'
and with that, one's bodily, verbal, and mental actions are unwholesome.

It is like someone who does not see and thinks they do not see, does not hear, does not discriminate, and does not cognize, but thinks they do not cognize. They do not think this, do not accept it, do not see it, do not desire it, and do not have the wisdom that they see, hear, discriminate, and cognize.

It is like someone who sees and thinks they see, hears, discriminates, and cognizes, and thinks they cognize. They do not think this, do not accept it, do not see it, do not desire it, and do not have the wisdom that they do not see, hear, discriminate, or cognize.
This is called engaging in unwholesome actions and engaging in inverted actions.
What is meant by engaging in neither unwholesome actions nor inverted actions?
Answer:
It is like someone who sees that there are consequences, and sees in this way and speaks in this way:
There are actions and there are consequences of actions.
Their bodily, verbal, and mental actions are wholesome.

It is like someone who does not see existence and has the thought of not seeing, does not hear, does not discriminate, and does not cognize existence and has the thought of not cognizing. With this thought, this forbearance, this view, this desire, and this wisdom, he thinks, I do not see, do not hear, do not discriminate, and do not cognize.

It is like someone who sees existence and has the thought of seeing, hears, discriminates, and cognizes existence and has the thought of cognizing. With this thought, this forbearance, this view, this desire, and this wisdom, he thinks, I see, hear, discriminate, and cognize.
This is called practice that is not unwholesome, but this practice is not inverted.
The same applies to the non-existent.
If one possesses unwholesome actions, does one also possess actions of the form and formless realms?
Answer:
It is like this, if one possesses unwholesome actions, one also possesses actions of the form and formless realms.
Can one possess actions of the form and formless realms without possessing unwholesome actions?
Answer:
There are, if one is born in the desire realm and desire love has ended, or if one is born in the form realm.
If one possesses wholesome actions of the desire realm, does one possess wholesome actions of the form and formless realms?
Answer:
One may possess wholesome actions of the desire realm but not wholesome actions of the form and formless realms.
How does one possess wholesome actions of the desire realm but not wholesome actions of the form and formless realms?
Answer:

If one is born in the desire realm and does not sever the wholesome roots, but does not obtain a wholesome mind of the form and formless realms, this is called possessing wholesome actions of the desire realm but not wholesome actions of the form and formless realms.
How does one possess wholesome actions of the form and formless realms but not wholesome actions of the desire realm?
Answer:

If one is born in the form realm and obtains a wholesome mind of the formless realm, this is called possessing wholesome actions of the form and formless realms but not wholesome actions of the desire realm.
How does one possess wholesome actions of the desire realm and wholesome actions of the form and formless realms?
Answer:

If one is born in the desire realm and obtains a wholesome mind of the form and formless realms, this is called possessing wholesome actions of the desire realm and wholesome actions of the form and formless realms.
How does one not accomplish wholesome conduct in the desire realm but not wholesome conduct in the form and formless realms?
Answer:
Cutting off the wholesome roots is called not accomplishing wholesome conduct in the desire realm but not wholesome conduct in the form and formless realms.
If one accomplishes conduct in the desire realm, do they accomplish conduct in the form realm?
Answer:
So it is.
If one accomplishes conduct in the form realm, do they accomplish conduct in the desire realm?
Answer:
So it is.
If one accomplishes conduct in the desire realm, do they accomplish conduct in the formless realm?
Answer:
So it is. If one accomplishes conduct in the desire realm, they accomplish conduct in the formless realm.
Can one accomplish conduct in the formless realm without accomplishing conduct in the desire realm?
Answer:
Yes, if one is born in the formless realm.
If one accomplishes conduct in the desire realm, do they accomplish uncontaminated conduct?
Answer:
One may accomplish conduct in the desire realm without accomplishing uncontaminated conduct.
How does one possess desire realm activities but not pure activities?
The answer is:
If ordinary people are born in the desire or form realms, they are said to possess desire realm activities but not pure activities.
How does one possess pure activities but not desire realm activities?
The answer is:
Immaculate people born in the formless realm are said to possess pure activities but not desire realm activities.
How does one possess desire realm activities and pure activities?
The answer is:
Immaculate people born in the desire or form realms are said to possess desire realm activities and pure activities.
How does one not possess desire realm activities and pure activities?
The answer is:
Ordinary people born in the formless realm are said not to possess desire realm activities and pure activities.
If one possesses form realm activities, do they possess formless realm activities?
The answer is:
It is so that if one possesses form realm activities, they possess formless realm activities.
Can one possess formless realm karma but not possess form realm karma?
Answer:
There are, those born in the formless realm.
If one possesses form realm karma, do they possess pure karma?
Answer:
There are those who possess form realm karma but not pure karma.
How does one possess form realm karma but not pure karma?
Answer:
Ordinary beings born in the desire realm and form realm, these are said to possess form realm karma but not pure karma.
How does one possess pure karma but not form realm karma?
Answer:
The undefiled born in the formless realm, these are said to possess pure karma but not form realm karma.
How does one possess form realm karma and pure karma?
Answer:
The undefiled born in the desire realm and form realm, these are said to possess form realm karma and pure karma.
How does one not possess form realm karma and pure karma?
Answer:
Ordinary people reborn in the formless realm are said to not possess form realm activities and pure activities.
If one possesses formless realm activities, do they possess pure activities?
Answer:
It is like this, if one possesses pure activities, they possess formless realm activities.
Can one possess formless realm activities but not pure activities?
Answer:
There are, namely ordinary people.
If one possesses desire realm activities, form realm activities, formless realm activities, and pure activities, where will they be reborn after the end of their life?
Answer:
Either in the desire realm, form realm, formless realm, or nowhere.
The third chapter on harming sentient beings in the Abhidharma is finished. The Sanskrit version has 309é¦–ç›§ and 4,631 words.
